context: Quantitative soil to leaf water relationships and their impacts on BVOC emissions are needed to improve BVOC emission model performance under drought stress conditions.  [1] Isoprene emissions from poplar (Populus spp.) plantations can influence atmospheric chemistry and regional climate.  [2] These emissions respond strongly to temperature, [CO2], and drought, but the superimposed effect of these three climate change factors are, for the most part, unknown.  [3] Performing predicted climate change scenario simulations (periodic and chronic heat and drought spells [HDSs] applied under elevated [CO2]), we analyzed volatile organic compound emissions, photosynthetic performance, leaf growth, and overall carbon (C) gain of poplar genotypes emitting (IE) and nonemitting (NE) isoprene.  [4] We aimed (1) to evaluate the proposed beneficial effect of isoprene emission on plant stress mitigation and recovery capacity and (2) to estimate the cumulative net C gain under the projected future climate.  [5] During HDSs, the chloroplastidic electron transport rate of NE plants became impaired, while IE plants maintained high values similar to unstressed controls.  [6] During recovery from HDS episodes, IE plants reached higher daily net CO2 assimilation rates compared with NE genotypes.
